descriptions.intro_required: Complete the Introductory Lesson (Day 0) first before proceeding to chords!

tips.be_patient: Be patient, progress comes with time

Em.instructions: Place finger 2 on the second fret of the A string (5th string) and finger 3 on the second fret of the D string (4th string). Leave the other strings open.
Em.tip: This is one of the easiest chords! Make sure your fingers are curved and don't touch the other strings.

Am.instructions: Place finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, and finger 3 on the second fret of the G string. Don't play the low E string.
Am.tip: Keep your thumb behind the guitar neck for better support. This chord appears in thousands of songs!

C.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, finger 3 on the third fret of the A string. G and high E strings remain open.
C.tip: This chord can be a bit challenging at first. Make sure to press the strings firmly and that each note sounds clean.

G.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the A string, finger 2 on the third fret of the low E string, finger 3 on the third fret of the B string, finger 4 on the third fret of the high E string.
G.tip: Use your fingertips and keep them curved. It's normal for this chord to be difficult at first, but with practice it becomes natural.

D.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the G string, finger 2 on the second fret of the high E string, finger 3 on the third fret of the B string. Only play the top 4 strings.
D.tip: Focus on playing only the strings that should sound. The two lowest strings (E and A) should not be played in this chord.

E.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the G string, finger 2 on the second fret of the A string, finger 3 on the second fret of the D string. The E strings remain open.
E.tip: This is a fundamental chord! Make sure finger 1 doesn't accidentally touch the B string.

A.instructions: Place fingers 1, 2, and 3 all on the second fret of the D, G, and B strings respectively. The A string stays open, high E open.
A.tip: Try using just one finger (like a barre) to press the three strings on the second fret - this will make transitions to other chords easier.

Dm.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the high E string, finger 2 on the second fret of the G string, finger 3 on the third fret of the B string. Play only the top 4 strings.
Dm.tip: Like the D major chord, avoid playing the low E and A strings. The sound should be more melancholic than D major.

F.instructions: This is a barre chord. Use finger 1 to press all strings on the first fret, then place the other fingers: finger 2 on the second fret of the G string, fingers 3 and 4 on the third fret of the A and D strings.
F.tip: This is the first really challenging chord! The barre requires strength and practice. Start by practicing just the barre, then add the other fingers.

B7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the D string, finger 2 on the second fret of the A string, finger 3 on the second fret of the G string, finger 4 on the second fret of the high E string.
B7.tip: This chord has a jazzy sound and is widely used in blues. The B string stays open, creating an interesting sound.

Bm.instructions: Use a mini-barre with finger 1 on the second fret (A and high E strings), finger 2 on the third fret of the B string, fingers 3 and 4 on the fourth fret of the D and G strings.
Bm.tip: This is another challenging chord. You can use a full barre on the second fret if it's more comfortable.

G7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the high E string, finger 2 on the second fret of the A string, finger 3 on the third fret of the low E string. The D, G, and B strings remain open.
G7.tip: This chord is very similar to G major, but with the pinky on the first fret of the high E string. It gives a more bluesy sound.

C7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, finger 3 on the third fret of the A string, finger 4 on the third fret of the G string.
C7.tip: Based on the C major chord, but with an additional note that creates tension. Widely used in progressions going to F.

A7.instructions: Finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, finger 3 on the second fret of the B string. The A, G, and E strings remain open.
A7.tip: One of the easiest seventh chords! Widely used in blues and country. It has an open and resolute sound.

D7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the second fret of the G string, finger 3 on the second fret of the high E string. D string stays open.
D7.tip: Very similar to D major, but with finger 1 on the first fret of the B string. Creates tension that resolves well to G.

E7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the G string, finger 2 on the second fret of the A string. All other strings remain open.
E7.tip: Even easier than E major! Just remove one finger from the E chord. Widely used in blues and rock.

Am7.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string. The A, G, and E strings remain open.
Am7.tip: A softer version of Am. Widely used in jazz and bossa nova. It has a more sophisticated and relaxing sound.

Em7.instructions: Only finger 2 on the second fret of the A string. All other strings remain open.
Em7.tip: The easiest chord of all! Just one finger. It has a very open and ethereal sound, perfect for ballads.

Dm7.instructions: Use finger 1 to make a mini-barre on the first fret (B and high E strings), finger 2 on the second fret of the G string.
Dm7.tip: A jazzy and sophisticated sound. The mini-barre can be challenging at first, but it's very useful to master.

Cmaj7.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the D string, finger 2 on the third fret of the A string. The G, B, and E strings remain open.
Cmaj7.tip: A very beautiful and sophisticated chord. Softer than C7, it has a dreamy sound perfect for ballads.

Fmaj7.instructions: Barre with finger 1 on the first fret (low E and B strings), finger 2 on the second fret of the G string, fingers 3 and 4 on the third fret of the A and D strings.
Fmaj7.tip: Similar to F major, but without pressing the high E string in the barre. Creates a more open and jazzy sound.

Gsus4.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the B string, finger 2 on the third fret of the low E string, finger 3 on the third fret of the A string, finger 4 on the third fret of the high E string.
Gsus4.tip: A widely used passing chord. Creates suspense and tension that resolves well to G major. Widely used in rock.

Dsus4.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the G string, finger 2 on the third fret of the B string, finger 3 on the third fret of the high E string.
Dsus4.tip: Creates beautiful tension that resolves to D major. Widely used in folk and country songs to add movement.

Cadd9.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the D string, finger 2 on the third fret of the A string, finger 3 on the third fret of the B string.
Cadd9.tip: A more colorful version of C major. Adds a note that gives a more modern and interesting sound.

G/B.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the A string, finger 2 on the third fret of the B string, finger 3 on the third fret of the high E string.
G/B.tip: A very useful passing chord. The different bass creates a melodic line in the bass, widely used in descending progressions.

F#m.instructions: Full barre with finger 1 on the second fret, finger 3 on the fourth fret of the A string, finger 4 on the fourth fret of the D string.
F#m.tip: Based on the Em shape, but with a barre on the second fret. This is good practice for mastering barres.

Bb.instructions: Barre with finger 1 on the first fret (A and high E strings), finger 2 on the third fret of the D string, fingers 3 and 4 on the third fret of the G and B strings.
Bb.tip: Another barre chord. Very common in songs in flat keys. Practice the barre separately first.

A#dim.instructions: Finger 1 on the first fret of the A string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, finger 3 on the second fret of the B string.
A#dim.tip: A passing chord with a unique and mysterious sound. Widely used to create tension and interesting harmonic movement.

Esus4.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the A string, finger 2 on the second fret of the D string, finger 3 on the second fret of the G string.
Esus4.tip: Creates beautiful tension that resolves to E major. Widely used at the end of musical phrases to add drama.

Asus4.instructions: Finger 1 on the second fret of the D string, finger 2 on the second fret of the G string, finger 3 on the third fret of the B string. The A and high E strings remain open.
Asus4.tip: ðŸŽ‰ Congratulations on reaching Day 30! This chord is perfect for 'Free Fallin'' by Tom Petty. It creates beautiful tension that resolves to A major. Practice switching between D, Dsus4, and Asus4 - this is the entire song! Try with a capo on fret 3 to match the original recording.
